awd_titl_txt: NCS-FO: Collaborative Research: Understanding Individual Differences in Cognitive Performance: Joint Hierarchical Bayesian Modeling of Behavioral and Neuroimaging Data
awd_abstract_narration:
Understanding the complex determinants of individual health and wellbeing is critical for the promotion and maintenance of a healthy world population.  Wellbeing may be understood not only as the absence of physical and mental illness but also as the quality of life and optimal functioning of individuals. It is well known that individuals vary tremendously in terms of cognitive abilities and dispositions, as seen from performance on high-order cognitive tasks, decision-making preferences, and emotional competencies. However, the neural underpinnings of much of this variability are poorly understood: It is unclear how individual differences in brain structure and function across tasks and processes are linked to abilities and competencies. This project explores a mathematical and computational framework for investigating a large-sample neuroimaging and behavioral dataset in order to improve our understanding of individual differences in cognitive performance. An ultimate goal of the project is to predict individual cognitive performance in novel, real-world situations based on observed (past) behavioral and neuroimaging data and contribute to the understanding of cognitive health and wellbeing of individuals. The project will also offer many training opportunities for the next generation of scientists. 

The technical approach will build on and integrate recent advances in cognitive science, neuroscience, statistics, and machine learning. Statistical models will integrate data from both brain imaging and behavioral tests to generate predictions that otherwise may not be possible with a single source of data. The research will go beyond establishing and explaining individual differences to predicting individual cognitive performance in a variety of tasks.

por.por_cntn:
The main objective of the project was to understand the neural underpinnings of individual differences in cognitive tasks. Many statistical analyses in cognitive science and cognitive neuroscience ignore individual differences and report results that are aggregated over individuals. Our goal in this project was to develop statistical and computational tools that take individual differences in neuroimaging as well as behavioral data into account and to examine how these individual differences are stable across cognitive tasks.

 

Towards this end, we conducted a machine learning study (Gaut, Li, Turner, Cunningham, Lu, & Steyvers, 2019) of a large-scale dataset that consists of neuroimaging data in a variety of behavioral tasks. Previous research has found that functional connectivity can accurately predict the identity of a subject performing a task and the identity of the task being performed. We compared the diagnosity of functional connectivity with that of an alternative statistic: blood-oxygen-level-dependent (BOLD) variability. Conceptually, functional connectivity relates to the underlying network of brain regions and is based on the covariation between brain regions, whereas BOLD variability is a region-specific measure based on the variance within each brain region. We showed that both functional connectivity and BOLD variability are predictive of task and subject, even across scanning sessions separated by multiple years. Given our findings that the variability of the BOLD signal can account for individual and task differences, we introduced a new type of statistical modeling framework that other researchers can use to account for individual differences and task effects (Gaut, Li, Lu, Steyvers, 2019). This new framework extends standard analyses by modeling both the mean and the variance in BOLD activation as a function of experimental design. 

 

We also developed and extended hierarchical Bayesian models to account for individual differences across behavioral as well as neuroimaging data and wrote a book on joint modeling (Turner, Forstmann, & Steyvers, 2019) to better explain our hierarchical Bayesian modeling framework to a large audience. The book gives several examples on how the joint modeling framework can be applied to neuroimaging and behavioral data and how to generate predictions that may not be possible with only a single level of analysis or modality. The proposed joint hierarchical Bayesian modeling approach bridges research in cognitive science and cognitive neuroscience and can be applied to a wide range of investigations. In addition, we have published a turial on joint modeling (Palestro, Bahg, Sederberg, Lu,  Steyvers, Turner, 2017), and applied the Hierarchical Bayesian analyses on BOLD time series (Molloy, Bahg,  Li,  Steyvers, Lu,  & Turner, 2019) and to reveal individual differences in the neural dynamics of response inhibition (Molloy, Bahg, Lu & Turner, 2019)

 

To train graduate students and postdocs on these new modeling tools, we organized a workshop on joint modeling with 12 invited speakers and 32 attendees (not counting the presenters). In this workshop, a number of tutorial sessions on joint modeling were presented for graduate students and postdocs to provide them with essential skills to apply the hierarchical Bayesian modeling framework on their own datasets. Overall, the development and implementation of the joint hierarchical Bayesian modeling framework has offered many opportunities for training the next generation of scientists that combine approaches from cognitive science as well as cognitive neuroscience.
